content: The "Employee Free Choice Act of 2007" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions for streamlining union certification. The "Employee Free Choice Act of 2007" streamlines union certification by amending Section 9(c) of the National Labor Relations Act to investigate petitions for collective bargaining representation when a majority of employees in a unit wish to be represented by a specific individual or labor organization. If valid authorizations are signed by a majority of employees and no other representative is certified, the Board shall proceed accordingly. The Board will certify the individual or labor organization as the representative if a majority of employees in a unit wish to be represented. Guidelines and procedures will be developed for the designation of a bargaining representative, including model language for collective bargaining authorization and procedures to establish the validity of signed authorizations. Amendments are made to the National Labor Relations Act to streamline union certification processes. Amendments to the National Labor Relations Act include changes to streamline union certification processes, such as modifying unfair labor practices related to petitions and certifications. SEC. 3. FACILITATING INITIAL COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGREEMENTS. Section 8 of the National Labor Relations Act is amended to include provisions for establishing an initial collective bargaining agreement within 10 days of a written request from a newly organized or certified labor organization. Bargaining must commence promptly and efforts made to reach an agreement within 90 days. The National Labor Relations Act is amended to include provisions for establishing an initial collective bargaining agreement within 10 days of a written request from a newly organized or certified labor organization. If parties fail to reach an agreement, either party may request mediation from the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. If mediation efforts fail, the dispute will be referred to an arbitration board. The arbitration panel will settle disputes between parties according to regulations set by the Service, with the decision being binding for 2 years unless mutually amended in writing. SEC. 4. STRENGTHENING ENFORCEMENT. Injunctions against unfair labor practices during organizing drives are addressed in the amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act. This amendment specifies actions that constitute unfair labor practices by employers. The amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act addresses unfair labor practices during organizing drives, including actions that significantly interfere with employees' rights. Preliminary investigations of such charges are given priority over other cases. The amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act prioritizes preliminary investigations of unfair labor practices during organizing drives. Additionally, remedies for violations include backpay for discrimination against employees seeking representation by a labor organization. The amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act allows for back pay and liquidated damages for employees discriminated against while seeking representation by a labor organization. Additionally, civil penalties are imposed on employers who willfully commit unfair labor practices during organizing drives. The amendment to Section 10(l) of the National Labor Relations Act allows for civil penalties of up to $20,000 for employers who commit unfair labor practices during organizing drives.
